choices.text: Only Acyclovir to the mother and baby
VZIG to both mother and baby, but no acyclovir to be given
VZIG to baby + Acyclovir to mother as well as baby
Nothing active is needed since the child is asymptomatic

questions.text: What is the therapy of choice in an asymptomatic baby born to a pregnant female who gets chicken pox one day prior to delivery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-risk period:
    • Maternal varicella infection from 5 days before to 2 days after delivery places the neonate at very high risk of severe neonatal varicella.
    • This condition is called Neonatal Varicella Syndrome.
  • Reason for severity:
    • Infection is acquired transplacentally as a result of maternal viremia, which can occur up to 48 hours before the onset of maternal rash.
    • During this time, the mother has not developed sufficient protective antibodies, so the infant receives a large viral load without passive antibody protection.
  • Course of illness in the baby:
    • The infant's rash usually appears toward the end of the 1st week to the early part of the 2nd week of life, although it may appear as early as 2 days after birth.
  • Mortality:
    • Perinatally acquired varicella in this window carries high mortality.

Recommended management

  1. VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immune Globulin)
    • Given to the newborn as soon as possible after birth to provide passive immunity.
  2. Acyclovir
    • Given to the mother to manage her own varicella infection.
    • For the newborn: Start IV acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hr) when lesions appear despite VZIG.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Only Acyclovir to the mother and baby (Option A): Passive immunization with VZIG is critical to prevent severe neonatal disease.

VZIG to both mother and baby, no Acyclovir (Option B): Mother still requires antiviral therapy to control her varicella. Infant may still need acyclovir if lesions develop despite VZIG.

Nothing is needed because the child is asymptomatic (Option D): Incorrect: The asymptomatic infant is at high risk of developing severe varicella due to maternal infection in the critical window.

choices.text: Antipruritic agents like Cetirizine can be safely given
Acyclovir should be started within 24-48 hr of rash for optimum efficacy, if indicated
Acyclovir is unsafe in neonates with suspected varicella

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding management of chicken pox, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acyclovir is safe and indicated in neonates with suspected or confirmed varicella, especially when maternal infection occurs from 5 days before to 2 days after delivery.
  • This is because maternal antibodies haven't developed in time to protect the baby via passive immunity.
  • These neonates are at high risk for severe disseminated varicella (Neonatal Varicella Syndrome), which can lead to pneumonitis, hepatitis, encephalitis, and even death.
  • Therefore, IV acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours for 10-14 days) is the recommended treatment, not unsafe.

Explanation of the Other Options:

Aspirin should be avoided (Option A): Aspirin is contraindicated due to the risk of Reye syndrome, especially when used during viral illnesses like varicella or influenza. Reye syndrome involves acute non-inflammatory encephalopathy and hepatic dysfunction, with high mortality. Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is the preferred antipyretic in chickenpox.

Antipruritic agents like Cetirizine can be safely given (Option B): Chickenpox causes intense itching, which can lead to scratching and secondary bacterial infection. Oral antihistamines like cetirizine, levocetirizine, or hydroxyzine are used to relieve pruritus. These agents are safe and effective in both children and adults.

Acyclovir should be started within 24-48 hr of rash for optimum efficacy, if indicated (Option C): Oral acyclovir (20 mg/kg/dose 4 times/day for 5 days), when started within 24 hours of rash onset, reduces duration of fever, total number of lesions and formation of new lesions. It is not routinely required in healthy, immunocompetent children but is indicated for adolescents, immunocompromised individuals, neonates and for complicated or severe varicella

questions.text: A child presented with febrile illness, followed by altered perception of objects and occasional hallucinations. He was labelled as "Alice in Wonderland" Syndrome. This is seen with which among the following viral infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alice in Wonderland Syndrome (AIWS)

  • Also known as Todd's Syndrome or Dysmetropsia.
  • A rare neurological disorder characterized by visual perceptual distortions, most classically:
    • Micropsia: Objects appear smaller than they are
    • Macropsia: Objects appear larger than they are
    • Distorted time perception
    • Altered body image (limbs or head may feel bigger or smaller)
  • Occasionally accompanied by hallucinations.

Association with EBV:

  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) can present with neuropsychiatric symptoms, including AIWS, even in otherwise healthy children.
  • It can be the first presenting symptom in infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV.

Explanation of other options:

HIV (Option B): HIV can cause chronic neurological syndromes (HIV encephalopathy, AIDS dementia), but not typically AIWS. Perceptual distortion is rare in early or acute HIV infection in children.

CMV (Option C): Congenital CMV causes sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, and developmental delay, but does not cause perceptual distortions or AIWS.

HSV (Option D): HSV (especially HSV-1) can cause temporal lobe encephalitis and hallucinations, but these are not typical of AIWS. AIWS is not a known manifestation of HSV infection.

questions.text: The X-linked lymphoproliferative (XLP) syndrome is classically associated with overwhelming infection by which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

X-linked lymphoproliferative (XLP) syndrome:

  • Also known as Duncan disease.
  • Inheritance: X-linked recessive.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Caused by mutations in genes such as SH2D1A (SAP protein).
    • These mutations lead to defective regulation of immune responses, particularly cytotoxic T cells and NK cells.

Association with EBV

  • Classic trigger: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.
  • Abnormal immune response:
    • When exposed to EBV, affected individuals have a massive, uncontrolled proliferation of lymphocytes, leading to:
      • Severe infectious mononucleosis
      • Fulminant hepatitis
      • Lymphoma
      • Hypogammaglobulinemia
    • Antibody production:
      • Impaired antibody response to EBV nuclear antigens, with variable or absent antibodies to viral capsid antigen.
    • Prognosis: Often unfavorable, with high mortality during primary EBV infection.

Explanation of other options:

Enteroviruses (Option B): Can cause infections in immunodeficient patients (like agammaglobulinemia), but not classically linked to XLP.

Catalase-positive bacteria (Option C): Associated with Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) due to defective NADPH oxidase, not XLP.

Neisseria meningitidis (Option D): Increased risk is seen with terminal complement deficiencies (C5-C9), not XLP.

choices.text: Patient is not infectious before clinical parotid enlargement
Salivary gland involvement includes only the parotid glands
Mumps orchitis frequently leads to infertility

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding Mumps?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mumps meningoencephalitis can appear:

  • Before parotitis,
  • Simultaneously with parotitis, or
  • After parotitis (most commonly ~5 days later).

Symptoms: headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, sometimes without significant salivary gland swelling.

Explanation of other options:

Patient is not infectious before clinical parotid enlargement (Option A): False. Viral shedding in saliva starts about 6 days before parotid swelling and continues up to 9 days after swelling onset. Thus, infectious period begins before parotitis appears.

Salivary gland involvement includes only the parotid glands (Option C): False. While the parotid gland is most commonly affected,  submandibular and sublingual glands can also be involved. Sometimes mumps affects these glands without parotid involvement.

Mumps orchitis frequently leads to infertility (Option D): False. Orchitis occurs in postpubertal males, unilateral in 70% of the cases and bilateral in 30%. Can cause testicular atrophy, but infertility is rare even in bilateral cases.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases presents with ulcers and blisters in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD):

  • Cause: Usually Coxsackievirus A16 (sometimes Enterovirus 71).
  • Clinical features:
    • Oral ulcers: Painful vesicles and ulcers in the mouth → sore throat, difficulty feeding.
    • Vesicular rash: Blisters on palms, soles, and sometimes buttocks.
    • Accompanied by fever and irritability.

Explanation of other options:

Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (Option A): Viral hemorrhagic fever seen in parts of India. Presents with high fever, myalgia, hemorrhagic tendencies, and thrombocytopenia. Rash is maculopapular; blisters and oral ulcers are not features.

Zika virus (Option B): Causes mild fever, conjunctivitis, arthralgia, and a maculopapular rash. No blisters or oral ulcers.

Erythema infectiosum (Parvovirus B19) (Option C): Characteristic "slapped cheek" rash on the face, followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the body. No blisters or ulcers.

questions.text: Transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly in the newborn is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Out of all the options, only Zika virus can be transmitted through mosquitoes.

  • Other clues are microcephalyin the child & infection of Hofbauer cells, which are again described in Zika Virus Infection.
  • Zika virus infection during pregnancy is a cause of microcephaly and other congenital malformations in the infant, including limb contractures, high muscle tone,eye abnormalities and hearing loss. These clinical features are collectively referred to as congenital Zika syndrome.
  • The risk of congenital malformations following infection in pregnancy remains unknown; an estimated 5-15% of infants born to women infected with Zika virusduring pregnancy have evidence of Zika-related complications.
  • Congenital malformationsoccur following both symptomatic and asymptomatic infection.
  • Zikainfection in pregnancy can also cause complications such as foetal loss, stillbirth, and preterm birth.

choices.text: Triad of SNHL, intracranial calcifications, and enamel hypoplasia
Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop SNHL later in life
If the mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about congenital CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maternal CMV IgG positivity means prior exposure and passive transfer of IgG antibodies to the fetus.
  • This significantly reduces the risk of congenital CMV infection, as primary infection during pregnancy is the main risk.
  • Risk of fetal infection:
    • Primary maternal CMV infection: 25-30%
    • Reactivation/reinfection: 1-3%
  • In developed countries: primary infection is the usual source.
  • In developing countries: reactivation/reinfection predominates due to high baseline maternal seropositivity.

Why the other options are incorrect

About 20-30% CMV infections are symptomatic (Option A): Only ~10% of congenital CMV infections are symptomatic at birth. 90% are asymptomatic.

Triad of SNHL, intracranial calcifications, and enamel hypoplasia (Option B): There is no described triad like this for CMV. Key features include Sensorineural hearing loss, periventricular intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Dental enamel hypoplasia is not a classic feature.

Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop SNHL later in life (Option C): False. SNHL risk is 60% in symptomatic infants and only 5-10% in asymptomatic infants. So most asymptomatic infants remain normal.

choices.text: MRI Brain for mesial temporal sclerosis

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with frequent myoclonic jerks for the past month. His teacher has noticed increased irritability, temper outbursts, and declining academic performance. On further inquiry, it is found that he was not vaccinated in infancy and had an episode of fever with rash at around 1 year of age that resolved spontaneously. EEG reveals periodic high-amplitude complexes. What investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The history is strongly suggestive of Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), a chronic, progressive, and nearly always fatal complication of measles.
  • Primary measles infection in infancy, especially in unvaccinated children, is a major risk factor.
  • SSPE typically presents 7-13 years after the initial measles infection.
  • Key presenting symptoms:
    • Myoclonic jerks (hallmark of stage II)
    • Irritability, cognitive decline, temper issues (stage I)
    • EEG abnormalities: Periodic Radermacher complexes
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by detection of Anti-measles IgG antibody in CSF, which reflects intrathecal production due to persistent defective measles virus in CNS.

Additional Clinical Staging of SSPE:

Other Diagnostic Clues:

  • EEG: Shows classic periodic Radermacher complexes
  • CSF: Raised measles-specific IgG (diagnostic)
  • Brain Biopsy: Was used earlier, now largely replaced by CSF serology

Treatment:

  • Intrathecal Interferon-Alpha is used (limited success)
  • Carbamazepine may help reduce myoclonic jerks

Explanation of Other Options:

Anti-Gq1b antibody in CSF (Option A): Seen in Miller Fisher syndrome (variant of GBS), not SSPE

EMG showing saw-tooth pattern (Option C): Applies to muscle disorders like myotonia; not relevant in SSPE, which is cortical

MRI for mesial temporal sclerosis (Option D): Relevant to temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE; MRI may be normal or show nonspecific white matter changes in SSPE

choices.text: 4 days before to 5 days after onset of rash
7 days after the onset of fever
5 days before to 2 days after the resolution of fever
2 days before to 3 days after resolution of rash

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Measles (caused by the measles virus, a paramyxovirus) is highly contagious and spreads via respiratory droplets.

  • Period of infectivity:
    According to OP Ghai (10th Edition, Pg 230–236), the infectious period of measles is from 4 days before to 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • This is when the virus is shed in high quantities through coughing, sneezing, and nasal secretions.
  • Isolation is recommended during this period to prevent transmission, especially in hospitals or among unvaccinated individuals.

Explanation of Other Options:

7 days after the onset of fever (Option B): Incorrect. This extends beyond the known infectious period and is not a standard reference timeframe.

5 days before to 2 days after the resolution of fever (Option C): Incorrect. Fever typically precedes the rash; infectivity is defined in relation to the rash, not fever resolution.

2 days before to 3 days after resolution of rash (Option D): Incorrect. Infectivity decreases significantly after the rash appears and is largely over by 5 days after its onset, not after resolution.

questions.text: A baby developed congenital toxoplasmosis. Presence of which among the following will predict a higher risk of severe infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HLA-DQ3+ predicts a more severe and fulminant course of congenital toxoplasma infection.

  • According to Nelson, In monozygotic twinswith congenital toxoplasmosis, the clinical pattern of involvement is most often similar, whereas in dizygotic twins the manifestations often differ.
  • The major histocompatibility complex class II gene DQ3appears to be common even among HIV-infected persons seropositive for T. gondii who develop toxoplasmic encephalitis, as well as in children with congenital toxoplasmosis who develop hydrocephalus.
  • These findings suggest that the presence of HLA-DQ3is a risk factor for severity of toxoplasmosis, in all patients including congenital toxoplasmosis.

choices.text: Give both antimicrobial prophylaxis and DT booster

questions.text: A 5-year-old child developed diphtheria and was managed appropriately. He has a 3-year-old sibling with whom he had close contact. The sibling is immunized with DPT and had got last diphtheria booster about 22 months back. What is to be done with the contact?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Close contacts of a diphtheria case, regardless of immunization status, are at risk and should receive antimicrobial prophylaxis, either with:

  • Benzathine Penicillin G
    • <6 years: 600,000 units IM
    • 6 years: 1,200,000 units IM
  • OR Erythromycin
    • 40-50 mg/kg/day divided QID PO for 10 days (max: 2 g/day)

Since this sibling is properly immunized and received a booster <5 years ago, there is no need to give another diphtheria toxoid booster. But prophylactic antibiotics must still be administered.

Diphtheria Contact Management:

Antimicrobial Prophylaxis:

Explanation of other options:

No prophylaxis needed (Option B): Incorrect. Even fully vaccinated individuals should receive antibiotic prophylaxis if they are close contacts, due to risk of asymptomatic carriage and transmission.

Give 1 dose of DT booster (Option C): DT booster is only indicated if the last diphtheria-containing vaccine was given >5 years ago or the child is inadequately immunized. This child had a booster just 22 months ago.

Give both antimicrobial prophylaxis and DT booster (Option D): Incorrect. Since the child is already immunized and boosted within 5 years, only prophylaxis is needed; booster is not indicated.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Toxin-mediated cardiotoxicity

  • Most common cause of death in diphtheria is myocarditis caused by diphtheria exotoxin.
  • Occurs in 10-25% of patients with respiratory diphtheria.
  • Responsible for 50-60% of diphtheria-related deaths.
  • The cardiac damage is direct toxin-mediated rather than immune or infection-driven.
  • Early signs: tachycardia out of proportion to fever, arrhythmias, or heart block.
  • Myocarditis typically manifests during the 2nd or 3rd week of illness, sometimes even earlier (which indicates worse prognosis).

Explanation of Other Options:

Toxic shock syndrome (Option A): Not a characteristic or common complication of diphtheria. Toxin shock-like presentations are more classically seen in Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenesinfections.

Palatal palsy (Option C): A toxin-mediated neurological complication, not a cause of death. Appears around the 2nd week, often mild and self-limiting.

Toxic neuropathy (Option D): Involves cranial nerves (like palatal and ocular palsy) and peripheral neuropathy (3-6 weeks post illness). Rarely fatal and tends to resolve over time with supportive care.

questions.text: A child with TB was started on corticosteroids. Steroids are effective in childhood tuberculosis in all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Corticosteroids do not act directly on Mycobacterium tuberculosis but are helpful in reducing the harmful inflammatory response caused by the host's immune system.
  • They are used in specific forms of tuberculosis where inflammation leads to significant morbidity or life-threatening complications.
  • They are not indicated in TB Pleural Effusion:
    • Inflammation in pleural TB is usually self-limiting.
    • There is no proven benefit of steroids in preventing complications or improving outcomes.
    • Steroids do not significantly alter the natural course or recurrence risk of pleural effusion.

Explanation of other options:

CNS Tuberculosis (e.g., Tubercular Meningitis) (Option A):

  • Mechanism:
    • Reduces basal meningeal inflammation, cerebral edema, and risk of hydrocephalus.
    • Improves neurological outcomes and survival.
  • Why important: Inflammation in the brain can cause raised intracranial pressure and long-term neurological damage.

Endobronchial TB (Option B):

  • Mechanism:
    • Decreases edema and granulation tissue in the airways.
    • Prevents or reduces bronchial obstruction and segmental collapse/emphysema.
  • Why important: Can help relieve respiratory distress in children.

TB Pericardial Effusion (Option D):

  • Mechanism:
    • Reduces pericardial inflammation and fluid accumulation, and lowers risk of constrictive pericarditis.
  • Why important: Prevents tamponade and long-term fibrosis of the pericardium.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low grade fever, headache and nasal congestion. He has a flushed face and has developed lacy reticular rash on the trunk and external surface of his arms and legs. He also has a strawberry-like tongue. Palms and soles are spared. His mother has been ill with low grade fever and joint stiffness and pain. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key features of Scarlet Fever (Group A Streptococcus, GAS):

  • Cause: GAS producing erythrogenic (pyrogenic) exotoxin.
  • Classic findings:
    • Rash:
      • Diffuse, finely papular, "sandpaper-like" erythematous rash.
      • Begins on neck, spreads to trunk and extremities.
      • Accentuated in skin folds (Pastia's lines).
      • Spares palms and soles.
    • Facial changes:
      • Flushed cheeks with circumoral pallor.
    • Tongue:
      • Initially white-coated → later "strawberry tongue" (erythematous with prominent papillae).
    • Course:
      • Rash fades after 3-4 days and is followed by desquamation.
    • Other features:
      • Pharyngitis: Red pharynx, enlarged tonsils with exudate, petechiae on soft palate.
      • Exposure: GAS can spread within families; the mother's fever and joint stiffness may reflect post-streptococcal complication (like rheumatic fever or reactive arthritis).

Explanation of other options:

Rubella (Option A): Rash- Pink maculopapular, starts on face, spreads downwards quickly. Findings- Tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy, Forchheimer spots. No strawberry tongue or rough texture rash.

Measles (Option B): Prodrome- High fever + 3 C's (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis). Koplik spots inside the mouth. Rash- Starts behind ears/hairline → spreads downward. Rash is confluent, not lacy or sandpaper-like.

Roseola infantum (HHV-6) (Option D): Age- Mostly infants (6 months-3 years). Fever precedes rash- High fever for 3-5 days → fever subsides → rash appears (starts on trunk, spreads to neck/face). No strawberry tongue.

questions.text: The following non-blanching rash seen in a child with splenic abnormality can be due to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical picture:
    • A rapidly progressing non-blanching rash (petechiae and purpura) in a child suggests purpura fulminans.
    • This is a classic early sign of fulminant meningococcal septicemia (meningococcemia).
  • Role of splenic abnormality:
    • Normal spleen function clears encapsulated organisms from the bloodstream.
    • Splenic dysfunction or asplenia (due to congenital causes or sickle cell autosplenectomy) leads to a very high risk of overwhelming sepsis with encapsulated bacteria, of which Neisseria meningitidis is a leading cause.
  • Progression in meningococcal sepsis:
    • Fever → nonspecific symptoms → rapid onset of petechial/purpuric rash → septic shock.
    • These lesions are non-blanching because of dermal capillary bleeding due to endotoxin-mediated vascular damage.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Causes skin abscesses, cellulitis, impetigo, and sometimes sepsis, but the rash is usually pustular or bullous, not a rapid petechial/purpuric rash. Does not classically cause purpura fulminans.

Escherichia coli (Option C): Mainly associated with neonatal sepsis, UTIs, and bacteremia. No characteristic purpuric rash.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D): Can cause ecthyma gangrenosum in immunocompromised patients, which appears as necrotic ulcers. This is different from the widespread, rapidly progressive purpuric rash of meningococcemia.

choices.text: Vaccination against encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type b is essential
Pneumococcal vaccine should include both PCV13 and PPSV23 for optimal protection
Vaccines should ideally be administered at least 2 weeks before planned splenectomy
Typhoid conjugate vaccine is mandatory prior to splenectomy to prevent overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding vaccination in a child planned for elective splenectomy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Typhoid conjugate vaccine is not routinely required as part of the pre-splenectomy immunization protocol.
  • OPSI is caused primarily by encapsulated organisms - Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type b.
  • Salmonella typhi (which causes typhoid) is not an encapsulated organism, and typhoid is not a common cause of OPSI.

Explanation for the Other Options:

Vaccination against encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae type b is essential (Option A): The spleen filters encapsulated bacteria, and splenectomy impairs this function. These vaccines are essential to prevent life-threatening sepsis or meningitis post-splenectomy.

Pneumococcal vaccine should include both PCV13 and PPSV23 for optimal protection (Option B): PCV13 (conjugate vaccine) induces strong T-cell-dependent immunity and is given first. PPSV23 (polysaccharide vaccine) covers more serotypes but induces T-cell-independent response. The combination offers broader and more durable protection.

Vaccines should ideally be administered at least 2 weeks before planned splenectomy (Option C): Giving vaccines 2 weeks prior ensures adequate immune response before the spleen is removed. If not feasible (e.g., emergency splenectomy), they can be given post-op after stabilization.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is indicated in the empirical treatment of uncomplicated enteric fever in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to current guidelines for the management of enteric (typhoid) fever in children:

For uncomplicated illness

  • First-line: Oral Cefixime
  • Alternative: Oral Azithromycin

For severe illness or complications

  • First-line: Injection Ceftriaxone
  • Alternative: Injection Aztreonam

Explanation of other options:

Injection Ceftriaxone (Option A): Reserved for severe or complicated cases (e.g., sepsis, intestinal perforation).

Oral Azithromycin (Option B): An alternative for uncomplicated illness, but not first-line.

Oral Ciprofloxacin (Option C): Not recommended empirically due to widespread resistance.

Explanation:

PANDAS stands for:

Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections.

  • It refers to a subset of pediatric patients who develop sudden-onset obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) or tic disorders following infection with Group A Streptococcus (GAS), i.e., Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • The pathogenesis is thought to involve molecular mimicry: the immune system forms antibodies against streptococcal antigens, which cross-react with basal ganglia neurons in the brain.
  • It’s similar to the mechanism in Sydenham chorea, a post-streptococcal neuropsychiatric complication of rheumatic fever.

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): Causes pneumonia, otitis media, meningitis-but not associated with PANDAS.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C): Causes skin infections, abscesses, osteomyelitis-not involved in PANDAS.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option D) : Common skin flora, associated with device-related infections, not neuropsychiatric disease.
